displayed_text: Patient: So we’re not going back to C__. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. I got that part of it. Family Member: Is any part of the change in the uh the lymph nodes, would that have anything to do with the testosterone or are you just saying that we’re not hormone sensitive so that probably did exacerbate the situation? Doctor: Well, we’ve been scanning you along the way. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So you know when we were on enzalutamide we saw things getting bigger. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And it looks like, you know, that’s always a concern with us giving the testosterone, the possibility it could make things worse. It sort of looks like it’s just a continuing monitor. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Things are progressing along at a certain pace, and we haven’t really changed the much of that. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Slow sort of speak with either thing that we tried.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: it as soon as possible. Okay but the chances of that happening are very small. The biggest thing is the second chemotherapy doesn’t have any danger to the nerves. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Like this one. Because this one that’s why I worry that you’re getting ten, twelve cycles now is your – are your nerves gonna start showing tingling, numbness, things like that? Patient: Yeah cuz see Doctor: Yeah. Patient: …my feet the most yeah… Doctor: Are tingling? Patient: Yeah, yeah I’ve been getting and it shrinks and so I’m saying wow. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: What the hell man. I don’t like that feeling. I don’t like… Doctor: No. Patient: It paralyzes or something. I don’t like that feeling.

Patient: That’s a different study. Doctor: Because that only works against the bone. Patient: Oh. Doctor: So unless I see and okay the bone scan, I was just looking, they did they compared it to a two-thousand-fourteen bone scan. So I really cannot tell too much. The only new findings are really this one on your bone scan – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: and that we are very well aware about that we know. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So those were there even before you started the Xofigo. Patient: Right. Doctor: The radiation. Patient: Right. Doctor: So right now I think we will be in just watch and wait mode because I see no recompelling reason to put you on a new treatment.

Patient: Right. Family Member: Why are you taking prednisone with it? Patient: So Doctor: So the Zytiga, so the way Xtandi works is, if you think that we talked before about the, the testosterone has to get into the cell and do stuff. It has to bind in something in the cell called receptors. So the best way to think about it is a ball and glove. Xtandi kind of, if, if the ball is testosterone, Xtandi looks like an orange. And so it gets in the glove, and it blocks the ball. It can’t get in there. Uh, Zytiga works in a different way. It blocks the enzymes that the body uses to make testosterone. So there’s all these different precursors. So start with cholesterol, and it goes through about ten steps, and ends at testosterone. When you block it, there’s some hormones that build up that can affect the kidney. Patient: Hum. Doctor: And those hormones can affect how you handle water and potassium. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So what they found is if you give a little bit of prednisone, which is also kind of a hormone, it balances that out. Uh, so we just give a once-a-day low dose, and that seems to be enough to keep the potassium normal. But some people don’t like prednisone. It makes them feel weird. It makes them gain weight. It makes them eat more. Patient: Oh. (Laughter) Doctor: And so, uh, the standard dose was twice a day. We found that if we just give it once a day, it’s enough to counterbalance the thing. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so I think either one would be fine. You know? I think choosing either one would be fine. But I think that’s what I would do next is- now, the way I do that is, the other side effect of these drugs are they’re very expensive. So what we do is, uh, we have a whole group here whose job is, if we decide we’re going to do one or the other, I will call them today, and say, “I want to put you on X.”

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: One caveat is, and this is going to seem more paradoxical, is that where patients go in this high-risk testosterone trial, the Transformer Trial, they also have to continue the Lupron. Patient: Lupron. Doctor: Which is a hormone-suppression. Patient: Yeah, yeah, we’ve had that before. Doctor: And that may seem paradoxical to you because on the one hand I’m telling you we’re going to give you testosterone back, and on the other hand I’m telling you we’re going to be giving you Lupron to suppress the testosterone. And it turns out this this is exactly what we want to do. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the purpose of this therapy, which we also call bipolar androgen therapy or BAT for short. We call it bipolar, not because it makes the patients bipolar. Doctor: But because we reach two extreme opposite levels of testosterone, opposite poles. Patient: Excuse me; does it have to be Lupron or it could be another hormone? Doctor: It has to be an injectable testosterone-lowering medication. It doesn’t have to be specifically Lupron. It can be any of the injectable hormone therapies. It cannot be an oral hormone therapy. Patient: Right. Okay, okay. Doctor: And typically it’s one of the hormone therapies that’s injected either every three months or every six months.

Patient: Well no. (laughs) Doctor: And that was for your liver right? Patient: I guess so. Doctor: Yeah, So that’s different for your hepatitis. Patient: Now she says go down lower though. Doctor: Yes. So that side perfect. That will be helpful but not enough for us. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we gotta go on a different hunt. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: What you… Doctor: Well good. You’re otherwise feeling okay? You look like a million buck from the, I mean I feel like I haven’t seen you in ages because I haven’t seen you in ages.

Patient: Put you in a hotel? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Hum. And that’s in what town? Doctor: No. I’ll tell you. I can find out. (Laughs) Patient: There’s no way, there’s no way of getting that? What medicine is that they give you for it? Doctor: It’s not the medicine. It’s the scan that is a specific one. That scanner is not available here or around here. Family Member: The scan will detect-? Doctor: If you have the PSMA. If you have that antigen or not in your cells. Then that will help us decide whether we put you on the study or not. Patient: And you can’t get it here in the states? Doctor: Not yet. Family Member: The scan. Doctor: The scan you can get.

Healthcare Professional: What did you give him because I have him coming back for the spinal? Doctor: He’ll come back after he gets scanned which will probably be like in a week or two. Healthcare Professional: Okay, so then we will, because he’s due to come back on the 18th and he’ll have research labs then, so that will be a different one. Doctor: I think so. We’ll try to make sure that we have a plan. Healthcare Professional: Okay Doctor: He can’t get rid of us now. Sit tight.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: So that’s where, that’s where I thought… Family Member: That’s what we just assumed it was… Doctor: Exactly. So now we’re just being super careful that you’re aware and you’re not bungee jumping and landing on your left hip and making that hurt worse. Doctor: Yeah I know. You’re not exactly outright denying me right now the bungee jumping that you’re starting to scare me or zip lining. Doctor: Terrific. Patient: I’m just thinking, I want to ask you now, Doctor: Nothing Patient: I, I’m pleased with where we’re at. Family Member: So. Doctor: I’m gonna order the x-ray. I’m gonna send you guys over there because they’re all screaming at me. They’re gonna… Patient: Order the x-ray for? Doctor: Hip.

Patient: I know. Okay. Family Member: Um. Healthcare Professional: Let me get your reports copied. Family Member: Do you mind if we, is it possible to sit in here and read through the consent? Just so we have… Doctor: That’s fine. It’s just that do you want to - are you okay with doing that? Patient: No, no, let’s take our time. Family Member: Okay. Alright. I didn’t mean not to take it home- Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: -but I meant if questions come up we could ask them. Doctor: Oh I see what you mean. Family Member: Let’s read it through in here and see if we have questions. I’m not asking you to sign it. Doctor: Yeah. Okay and then that way you – you know I’ll check back with you if you have questions.

Family Member: Is that Xtandi a, a injection or a pill or – Doctor: It’s a pill. He takes four pills a day. Family Member: Oh, alright. I get it. Doctor: Gives you fatigue, tiredness. Patient: I had two extra bottles I gave back to Family Member: And then, uh, and then he’s going to take it for awhile. And he’ll come down here and get -- in a month or how--how soon? Doctor: So what’s gonna happen is we’ll put the prescription in – Family Member: Yep. Doctor: They’ll let us know, and then by e-mail, we’re gonna – or in MyChart – we’re gonna know whether or not you can start it. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And then if you start it, then after two weeks – Family Member: Ahhhh.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But more concerning is just you have more lymph nodes or they’re not even technically lymph nodes they’re more… Patient: Nodules. Doctor: …nodules in the belly whereas before… Doctor: Yeah. It’s more of the schmutz that we talked about… Patient: Um hum. Doctor: …that was hard to characterize. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That schmutz has sort of formalized more into you can call them a nodule, a mass… Patient: Mass. Doctor: …a thingy, a whatever it is, but it’s the cancer. Patient: Mass.

Patient: No, no. Doctor: Bowels working okay? Patient: Yep. Family Member: But it went from one side to the other which and he does have kidney stones, but last night it was on this side, this morning that one stopped and it was on this side. Doctor: And now it’s gone? Patient: Yeah. I had a little bit over here on this side, but I mean I think it’s my back because I’ve had back… Family Member: Because kidneys wouldn’t do that. It wouldn’t push back and forth like that. Doctor: No and if it’s the lymph nodes that are pushing, there may be a little bit of pain from that. Family Member: From one side to the other but.. Doctor: Yeah. But it’s still, it doesn’t sound cancer related. It almost sounds muscle or… Family Member: I think his back’s out of whack. Doctor: Or back.

Patient: I think so, yeah. It’s still a little bit, it’s real tiny. It feels better than it did four weeks ago. Doctor: And the last time you had some seepage in your lower lung and you’re still a little tiny Patient: Yes. Doctor: That’s Last week and – And how Patient: I guess I need to keep putting the ointment on, you know. Doctor: And how’s your appetite? Patient: Good. Doctor: And weight? Patient: One-eighty seven. Doctor: Stable or up for you? Patient: A little up maybe. Doctor: Your bowels are working? Patient: Yep.

Patient: So when I get it on the eighth in terms of my work schedule; I’m an attorney; if I have a trial like the ninth or the tenth, can I - Doctor: Sure, you’ll be fine. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’ll be fine. Patient: Got-cha. No problem, thank you. Doctor: You’re welcome. Uhm, so if you’re going to do the eighth and I’m going to see you, D____ needs to talk to you about some medicine you’re going to take beforehand. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That keeps you from having the side effects. And she’ll give you a prescription. That’s the only other thing we’ll give you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Unless you think of anything else. Patient: The testosterone and the shot. Thank you very much. Have a good week. Doctor: All right. I’ll be waiting. Healthcare Professional: The effects of
